metadata.title: SDVOSB Contracts
metadata.description:
Start Your Government Contracting Business with the GovClose CERTIFICATION: https://www.govclose.com/sales-certification

Connect with Richard C. Howard
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/in/govclose

In this live session, I’ll break down why some companies are permanently shifting their federal sales strategy to subcontracting — and how you can do the same.

We’ll cover:

Best practices for successful subcontracting
- How to choose the right prime contractor
- What kinds of opportunities to pursue — and where to find them
- Tools that can help you win as a subcontractor

📲 Follow me on YouTube or LinkedIn @GovClose for the latest insights and strategies in government contracting!

key_points.text: The service disabled veteran owned small business (SDVOSB) certification program will be discussed, covering its purpose, eligibility, and utility.
Rick Howard, a former government acquisitions officer, managed over $82 billion in government contracts before founding Gov Close.
Gov Close trains sales executives in small businesses on government contracting.
The discussion focuses specifically on the service disabled veteran owned small business certification due to its relevance for veterans.
The application process for SDVOSB certification, including navigating the Small Business Administration (SBA) website, will be demonstrated.
The speaker, Rick Howard, has the SDVOSB certification and states it is not difficult to obtain.
Best practices for utilizing the SDVOSB certification will be shared, drawn from Rick Howard's acquisitions career in the Air Force and his consulting business.
The episode aims to provide tactical, hands-on guidance to help veterans decide if the SDVOSB certification is right for them and how to use it effectively.
Government contracting is acknowledged as not suitable for everyone and can be a time-consuming process.
The U.S. federal government is the world's largest purchaser of goods and services.
The government is mandated to purchase from small businesses, with the SBA setting goals for federal agencies.
Approximately 23% of federal spending, totaling around $180 billion last year, goes to small businesses.
Government purchases span a wide range, from landscaping and construction to satellite technology and social media management.
Most beneficial certifications for businesses (those that 'move the needle') involve an application and vetting process.
The 8a certification is a disadvantaged business certification with significant benefits, though it takes a long time to acquire.
The HubZone certification depends on a business's physical location, which can be checked on a HubZone map.
The Woman-Owned Small Business certification also requires an application through the SBA.
The Service Disabled Veteran-Owned Small Business (SDVOSB) certification is distinct from Veteran-Owned Small Business (VOSB) because SDVOSB has a specific contracting goal associated with it.
A percentage of government contracts is specifically targeted for award to SDVOSBs across federal agencies.
One federal agency, under a 'Veterans First' initiative, prioritizes looking at SDVOSB companies for contracts.
Certifications like SDVOSB should not be the sole focus; businesses must first have a viable product or service and excel at it.
It is recommended to first establish B2B or B2C sales before pursuing government contracts.
Government contracting is a challenging but potentially very lucrative long-term process.
The SDVOSB certification can significantly aid veterans in winning government contracts.
The primary goal is to help veterans make an informed decision on whether to pursue the SDVOSB certification.
The SDVOSB application process is relatively easy and straightforward, unlike other certifications.
The first step for application is the SBA website, specifically the SDVOSB section.
To qualify for SDVOSB, an individual must be a service disabled veteran, regardless of the percentage of disability.
Required documentation includes a disability letter from the VA.
Applicants must also have a registered business and a registration in SAM.gov.
It is strongly advised against paying third parties to assist with the SDVOSB certification application, as it is a process easily completed independently.
The SDVOSB application typically takes a couple of weeks to a month to process.
The VOSB certification does not have a specific contracting percentage goal like the SDVOSB.
A business must meet the small business size standard to qualify for the certification.

summary:
Rick Howard, a former government acquisitions officer who managed over $82 billion in contracts, introduces the Service Disabled Veteran Owned Small Business (SDVOSB) certification program. As the founder of Gov Close, an organization that trains sales executives in small businesses on government contracting, Howard aims to provide comprehensive insights into what the SDVOSB certification entails, who qualifies for it, how to apply, and critically, how to leverage it effectively. This discussion is part of a series on government contracting, with a specific focus on veterans.

The U.S. federal government is the world's largest buyer of goods and services and is legally mandated to procure a significant portion from small businesses, with the Small Business Administration (SBA) setting annual goals (around 23% or $180 billion last year). Howard explains that while many certifications exist, only a few like the 8a, HubZone, Woman-Owned Small Business, and specifically SDVOSB, truly impact a business's ability to secure government contracts. He emphasizes the distinct advantage of SDVOSB over general Veteran-Owned Small Business (VOSB) certification, noting that SDVOSB has specific contracting goals and is prioritized by certain federal agencies under initiatives like 'Veterans First'.

Howard provides practical advice, stressing that while SDVOSB can be a powerful tool, it is not an "easy button" for contracts; businesses must offer excellent products or services and consider B2B/B2C sales first. He walks through the SDVOSB application process via the SBA website, highlighting that it's straightforward and does not require paying third-party consultants. Key eligibility requirements include being a service-disabled veteran (any percentage), having a registered business, and a SAM.gov registration. The goal is for viewers to make an informed decision on whether to pursue the certification and to utilize it strategically if obtained.
